oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Creating unconnected ontology elements
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: Ontology elements (classes, object properties and datatype properties) are created isolated, with no relation to the rest of the ontology.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Defining wrong inverse relationships
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: Two relationships are defined as inverse relations when they are not necessarily inverse.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Merging different concepts in the same class
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: A class whose name refers to two or more different concepts is created.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Missing annotations
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall consists in creating an ontology element and failing to provide human readable annotations attached to it. Consequently, ontology elements lack annotation properties that label them (e.g. rdfs:label, lemon:LexicalEntry, skos:prefLabel or skos:altLabel) or that define them (e.g. rdfs:comment or dc:description). This pitfall is related to the guidelines provided in [5].

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Missing domain or range in properties
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: Object and/or datatype properties without domain or range (or none of them) are included in the ontology.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Equivalent properties not explicitly declared
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: The ontology lacks information about equivalent properties (owl:equivalentProperty) in the cases of duplicated relationships and/or attributes.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Inverse relationships not explicitly declared
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall appears when any relationship (except for those that are defined as symmetric properties using owl:SymmetricProperty) does not have an inverse relationship (owl:inverseOf) defined within the ontology.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Defining multiple domains or ranges in properties
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: The domain or range (or both) of a property (relationships and attributes) is defined by stating more than one rdfs:domain or rdfs:range statements. In OWL multiple rdfs:domain or rdfs:range axioms are allowed, but they are interpreted as conjunction, being, therefore, equivalent to the construct owl:intersectionOf. This pitfall is related to the common error that appears when defining domains and ranges described in [7].

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Misusing ontology annotations
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: The contents of some annotation properties are swapped or misused. This pitfall might affect annotation properties related to natural language information (for example, annotations for naming such as rdfs:label or for providing descriptions such as rdfs:comment). Other types of annotation could also be affected as temporal, versioning information, among others.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Using different naming conventions in the ontology
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: The ontology elements are not named following the same convention (for example CamelCase or use of delimiters as "-" or "_") . Some notions about naming conventions are provided in [2].

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Using recursive definitions
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: An ontology element (a class, an object property or a datatype property) is used in its own definition. Some examples of this would be: (a) the definition of a class as the enumeration of several classes including itself; (b) the appearance of a class within its owl:equivalentClass or rdfs:subClassOf axioms; (c) the appearance of an object property in its rdfs:domain or range rdfs:range definitions; or (d) the appearance of a datatype property in its rdfs:domain definition.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Equivalent classes not explicitly declared
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall consists in missing the definition of equivalent classes (owl:equivalentClass) in case of duplicated concepts. When an ontology reuses terms from other ontologies, classes that have the same meaning should be defined as equivalent in order to benefit the interoperability between both ontologies.

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: Untyped class
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: An ontology element is used as a class without having been explicitly declared as such using the primitives owl:Class or rdfs:Class. This pitfall is related with the common problems listed in [8].

oops:Pitfall.oops:Name: URI contains file extension
oops:Pitfall.oops:Description: This pitfall occurs if file extensions such as ".owl", ".rdf", ".ttl", ".n3" and ".rdfxml" are included in an ontology URI. This pitfall is related with the recommendations provided in [9].

oops:Suggestion.oops:Name: SUGGESTION: symmetric or transitive object properties.
oops:Suggestion.oops:Description: The domain and range axioms are equal for each of the following object properties. Could they be symmetric or transitive?
